{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3410656,"name":"Bowen","username":"boborious","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-23T20:27:46.611Z","cooked":"

Would you recommend teaching basic Java first or concepts used in WPILIB like PID controllers, subsystems, path planning, etc. for new FRC programmers?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-07-23T20:27:46.611Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":48,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":272.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469051,"topic_slug":"teach-basic-java-first-or-frc-specific-content","display_username":"Bowen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67307,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/teach-basic-java-first-or-frc-specific-content/469051/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3410659,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-23T20:40:57.732Z","cooked":"

Personally, as someone who has taken Java courses in college, I would want to have at least a basic exposure to Java before getting into FRC specific programming so you have a good foundation.

That said, there’s also only so much the average team can meaningfully teach in the time you have. In our teams case, most of the students we’ve brought into our coding group have had some previous programming experience prior to joining. We’ve done a lot of training and workshops with the more inexperienced kids, but really what we’d need is a programming class in the school itself to get them to where we’d like them to be. There just isn’t enough time otherwise.

One thing we have found that’s been helpful though is bringing up programming students through the FLL and FTC programs, since those use progressively more complex coding and it’s somewhat easier to adapt to the more complicated systems and code in FRC once you’ve been exposed to the earlier programs. Plus when you’re working on the scale of multiple years, it’s easier to have them pick things up as they go.

in the past 3 years of training fellow students, I’ve taught Java first, then WPILib
I have made a library of resources to train students called the LLK

lea.verou.me

Forget “show, don’t tell”. Engage, don’t show! • Lea Verou

Personally, people are goal oriented, help em reach their goals first to inspire them to learn the why later.

Engage, don’t show! • Lea Verou","clicks":26}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4297,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I'm Retired"},"post_url":"/t/teach-basic-java-first-or-frc-specific-content/469051/4","custom_user_title":"I'm Retired","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410667,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-23T20:57:56.826Z","cooked":"

Ideally, students have learned the fundamentals of Java, Python, or some programming language outside of FRC. Once they start with FRC, they step through example robot code with most of the basic functionality and see how Java is used in the robotics setting. Control theory is independent of programming and is a unique thing to learn. It is necessary to implement control with a program, so learning about the specific control classes and methods available also has to happen. Learning about more advanced capabilities such as path planning, vision, and simulation can come after someone has a good handle on the fundamentals of FRC programming.

If someone is starting in FRC without any programming background, they have an extra challenge. I suggest that they begin to learn Java from the robot code. Look at code that works and try to understand how it is put together. Look up things you don’t know (e.g. what is “private”). There will be A LOT of looking up. Try not to kill the experienced programmers with a million questions. Reserve the human questions for the things that still aren’t coming clear after a solid research effort. If someone likes programming and wants to continue, they can fill in their Java foundation and best coding practice foundation with coursework in parallel with FRC.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-07-23T20:57:56.826Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":128.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":469051,"topic_slug":"teach-basic-java-first-or-frc-specific-content","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/teach-basic-java-first-or-frc-specific-content/469051/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410683,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-23T21:55:15.146Z","cooked":"

Lots of good advice already posted and the Engage, don't show comes close to what my team does. All the theoretical advice aside and the practical advice is it depends on how much time the students want to spend on learning this material.

The students on my team put little time into learning Java and WPILib compared to some teams that hold summer sessions and many fall sessions. They consistently report that they hate sitting through Java lessons. They often don’t even make it through those lessons and have almost no knowledge of WPILib before the kickoff.

So what we did the past couple of years is beginning Java is taught for not many minutes before the students start to mostly copy the instructor code off the classroom board onto their Romi project. They get the Romi moving fairly quickly.

Last year we didn’t get to Command-based lessons although we did use command-based. (We abused it a bit but the students did pick up enough to do fairly well with it although they coded two or three times as many lines of code than needed.)

The upcoming season will have us getting the Romi running with Command-Based very early on. We won’t be spending much up-front time with beginning Java and iterative-robot.

We provide a list of beginning Java self-taught lessons for the beginner who wants to learn more independently but there are never many takers for the extra work.

So our answer is show the students beginning Java command-based code to run the Romi and they see what they typed makes it go the way it does.

As another sample point, I’m an advocate for going back and forth.

Start with the absolute basics. Types, math operations, if/if-else/else, functions, methods, classes. The first shelf in the toolbox.

Skip strings, skip making modules, skip arrays/lists/dictionaries/hash-maps, skip anything other than what it takes to call wpilib.

Then some robot basics - what is wpilib, how do you call it, how to get a very simple joysticks-to-motors tank drive to run. Which is a lot less about anything coding, and much more about “how does one make a robot?” Some very high level discussions about the “observe your world, do some calculation, change your output” is good to motivate this.

Finally, wrap back around to some of those other language concepts. They’re sometimes useful (IE, how do you assemble names of logging variables? How do you group your four swerve modules together?)

Finally finally, wrap back to more advanced robot topics. Closed loop control, path following, whatnot.

Critically, each step needs to have just enough motivation to keep the student learning, without making them feel like they’re just memorizing facts that may or may not be useful later. Make it clear why the steps are important now.
